As a resident physician who generally enjoys NYT health editorials, I believe that this one would have benefitted from a read-over by a combination of relevant parties (eg. oncologists, hospice RNs, general/palliative MDs, actuaries/statisticians) before hitting the press.
The flawed, unstated assumption at the crux of this article’s argument is that members of the medical community are accurate in predicting exactly when a patient with a terminal condition is going to pass away. In fact, we are not.
As with many other phenomena, the time between diagnosis and death for each of the different known end-of-life conditions (end-stage heart failure, advanced dementia, metastatic/terminal cancer, etc) occurs on its own normal curve or some close variant thereof. It is appropriate, rather than appalling, that 19% of people placed on hospice outlive their six-month “life expectancy.” Statistically, these folks encapsulate the tail of their disease’s bell curve. And individually, they often represent victories for the hospice modality of care. Aside from the small number of cases of frank Medicare fraud out there, hospice six-month-survivors are anything but "mistakes." Just ask them.
If our society considered it a waste of resources to have wrongly placed some folks on hospice who ultimately make it past six months, and thereby increased the “severity-of-illness” threshold we use for offering hospice care benefits, then many people in desperate need of this modality of care would miss out. Though our ability as physicians to predict remaining time for individuals is limited, what we CAN bring to the table is a reasonable approximation of the point after which further interventions (even the act of hospitalization itself) will no longer be of help to the patient. If patients beyond this point are denied hospice, medicine will likely be practiced ON them rather than FOR them during future hospitalizations, and we'll all be the worse for it.

comments.commentBody: No one is beyond attack by the greedy anymore--even the dying. The more vulnerable the target, the better. Apparently, for those who want to pay no taxes, it's not enough for the elderly to die. They have to die uncomforted and untended, unless someone can tend and comfort them at no cost or inconvenience to the important people of the world. It's enough to make you hope that Hell exists.

I help my 97-year-old friend get to the doctor, etc.. She is losing her memory, & when I was away I found that a surgeon had persuaded her to have a pacemaker put in (I learned this when his nurse called me to set a time.) I was shocked, & startefd doing rresearch, then asked her regular doctor a series of questions relevant to such a procedure, including one so simple, as: Can we get a second opinion (in this small town of about 30,000)?

When her regular doctor ended up admitting there seemed no real benefit to her having a pacemaker, I canceled for her. Later, she wore a heart monitor for 24 hours, & its interpreter said she cd. not benefit from a pacemaker.

I believe I've seen other cases of this, but no real proof. I esp. suspect that C-Pap for sleep apnea, really don't have sleep apnea, but are only sleeping abnormally when at a sleep clinic overnight -- including myself.
How much would those hospice patients cost Medicare if they spent 17 days (or 6 months) in an ICU?

After my retirement, in 2010, I authored a book intended on saving naïve health care consumers from themselves, and from an increasingly self-serving health care industry. These two factions together, provide the perfect storm for guaranteeing mismanaged care and prolific waste—and no venue demonstrates this more glaringly than end-of-life care within our nation’s nursing homes. As I point out in the book, more factions are able to charge for and be reimbursed for healthcare delivery than ever before. This has come about through creating “boutique” health care niches. The demand for boutique care is being driven by entrepreneurial interests, and, once brought to fruition, then being managed with corporation business tactics—i.e., for profit. “Incontinence centers,” “wound healing centers,” “sleep apnea centers,” etc. One of the most incredible niches of them all has been Hospices’ success at making care of the dying a specialty niche!! Has Medicare bothered to check recently the amount of money they are paying out to Hospice for assurance that dying is being managed correctly?! (Your article answered this for me.) The work horses being remunerated for staffing most of these niches are RNs and ARNPs, with a physician usually somewhere in the distant background getting a cut of the action, for his/her alleged supervisory service.
Could a professionally run, altruistic hospice service, for bonafide patients still residing in their own homes, be valuable to the system? Absolutely! But permitting hospices to enterprisingly ply their trade in nursing homes, where Medicare is already being charged by physicians, and where nursing salaries are implicitly paid by Medicare as well, is ludicrous. In the nursing homes, hospice care should be the responsibility of the attending physicians and nurses already being remunerated by Medicare for caring for the patients—anything else constitutes double dipping!---Alan D. Cato MD, F.A.A.F.P.

Hospice is a business. The company is paid daily whether or not services are provided. If an individual lives in a long term care facility such as a nursing home or assisted living, Hospice generally provides a duplication of services already being provided by the facility. A famous diagnosis Hospice likes to use to justify services for an older person is "debility." Some patients in long term care facilities have remained on Hospice services 4 years or more, and they only receive a once a week, fifteen minute visit from the nurse or social worker, and a rare physician visit. That should be a crime.

People often envision Hospice allowing people to "die with dignity" in their own home or in a Hospice House. This is an untruth. The person at home will NOT receive daily assistance with showers, morning activities, or respite for a caregiver. A worker will generally go to the home 1-2 times a week. If a person is admitted to a Hospice House for 24 hour care during the dying process, there is usually a 2 week maximum the person has to pass away, and if they live beyond that or improve, the family is responsible for finding alternative placement.

For people who are tryuly terminal with end-stage lymphoma or renal disease, Hospice services can be very helpful. But when Medicare dollars are being paid to unrendered services for "debility", then the regulations for Hospice should be tightened.

Wow! I can't believe this. I never expected to read so many comments defending this guy. I grew up in Chicago, live in southern Illinois, actually voted for Blagojevich twice, and I wanted nothing more than to see him convicted on all counts - but 17 is good. The guy is a slimy crook. I see nothing charming about his looks, demeanor or "average Joe" persona. I do agree that he is not very bright, but that does nothing to quell my extreme disdain for his complete lack of personal and professional integrity. I take offense at his arrogance, his betrayal of the trust of voters like myself and his belief that he could use "charm", bluster and verbosity to avoid consequences for his actions. He tried the same thing at his impeachment trial which I listened to on the radio. His subsequent removal from office was one of the only times I was proud of my state legislature. I have been particularly offended by his attempt to garner public support with book tours and reality show appearances. The wiretap tapes show that he had no respect for the people who elected him, nor for the constitution he had twice sworn to serve, and yes I believe his far fetched plans constitute criminal conspiracy.

I am a lifelong Democrat; however, the only true public servant in this sorry tale is Patrick Fitzgerald, whom I once had the honor of hearing speak in person. He has my utmost respect.

The costs associated with the shutdown will be borne by the ratepayers, as was the case with the closing of the Shoreham Nuclear Plant on Long Island. The customers were saddled with a 5% surcharge each year for 10 years by the then Governor Mario Cuomo. It was a sweet deal for LILCO whose stock went from $2.00 per share to about $14.00 after Cuomo's deal was made public. The decommissioning costs were hundreds of millions of dollars and were paid by the New York Power Authority, which were passed along to their customers. Mario Cuomo lost Long Island in a landslide to George Pataki in the next election. I'm sure Andrew is aware of the consequences of his fathers actions, so perhaps he plans on being in the White House before Entergy wins in the courts for their losses and New York ratepayers are the losers once again.

Thank you Governor Cuomo!  This aging plant is a menace to all New Yorkers.  The plant and its associated highly vulnerable storage facilities for spent fuel rods (three times the amount at Fukushima, same technology!) are vulnerable to earthquake, fire, and terrorist attack with no way to evacuate citizens in the wake of an accident.  It should never have been built so near a densely populated area.  The only thing I question is the reporter's buying into Entergy's oft cited claim that is supplies 25% of NYC and Westchester's power as if it were fact.  I have read figures elsewhere that it only supplies 5% of local power needs and that it sells the rest on the open market to localities from Maine to Ohio.  I wish the Times would investigate Entergy's claim and clarify how much power it really does supply downstate New Yorkers.

Most students in the DC school system were doing poorly, but 95% of teachers once got high ratings? Sounds just like today's mark inflation at university. Any surprise that most DC public school teachers evaluated now get worse marks than before, when administrators feared looking bad?

My high school over 50 years ago, was nothing like the average inner-city zoo that so many now attend. We had weekly tests in every subject. Tests were marked on a 100-point scale. An monthly average of 60 was pass. No marking on a curve. Those who did not work flunked out. We graduated 230 after starting 700 in 7th grade plus sizeable new in-take in 9th grade. The school was designed solely to get student performance. Work or loaf, students whose performance on tested content was under 60% left. The good part was it was real-world.

As for teachers, few were really good, most were average, but covered the assigned curriculum without deviating. Maybe 20% to 25% were a lot less good than they might have been. Those 20% or 25% usually mistook showing us how much they knew for actually teaching us something. This was especially common among math teachers. A few students followed and got really high marks (90% or better), but most were right at 60% or less. ( From one less good teacher's class to another, the few making 90% or better were not over 3 out of 36.)

University had very few really good profs. Most, however, were good. But again 20% to 25% mistook showing us how much they knew for actual teaching.

So there is lots of room for improved teaching in public primary and secondary schools. Then with improved teaching, it is only fair to flunk students who for whatever reason cannot keep up . Passing should signify subject mastery, not a meaningless, social promotion for just holding on year after year. The US economy is less self-contained than in 1958. Now import duties do not protect unskilled US workers from competition by unskilled foreign workers.

A perfect example of why America is spiraling downward. We don't want nuclear, we don't want coal, we don't want natural gas, we don't want any new power lines. But come the day when there isn't enough power who will be whining the loudest? The very same ones who are whining now.

And, in keeping with family tradition, AC's kid will be leading the band. But that's okay. NYC will be half-deserted, NYS will be Greece or Italy, and the rest of the country will absorb the jobs and the wealth. Enjoy your life with candles. But please, please keep your new life style within your own borders.

It seems that people who cite the cleanliness and safety of nuclear energy must be forgetting the steadily growing piles of highly radioactive spent fuel for which we have yet to construct any "permanent" and "safe" storage facilities.

According to the website of the nuclear energy institute a typical nuclear power plant generates 20 metric tons of used fuel per year. The entire U.S. nuclear industry generates 2000 - 2300 metric tons of used fuel per year. "Over the past four decades, the entire industry has produced about 65,200 metric tons of used nuclear fuel." At the end of 2010, New York state was home to 3450 metric tons of used nuclear fuel. - NEI website accessed 6/29/2011.

I applaud Governor Cuomo's apparent awareness of these facts and his desire to shut down Indian Point.
